title: Local Ad
description: Michael tries to make a local Dunder Mifflin commercial that is better than the one the professional ad agency made for them. Meanwhile, Andy tries to confide in Dwight about his new relationship with Angela.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Yeah! Everything! Oh it's all good, it's all good. Phyllis!

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Dancing babies!

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Dancing babies! I love it! I love it!

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: We are making a commercial for Dunder Mifflin today. Our first ad ever.  Corporate purchased some air time in local markets to spread the word about Dunder Mifflin Infinity and they are even sending up a professional ad company to help us make it later so... it's uh, not too shabby.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Best ad ever. [sings in the tune of the "Kit Kat theme song"] Gimme a break, gimme a break, break me off a piece of that... I am totally blanking. What is the thing?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Nobody tell him!

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: What? No, why?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: You got it, you're so close!

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: [singing] Break me off a piece of that... huh huh huh... br- applesauce.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Break me off a piece of that applesauce, I don't think...

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Break me off a piece of that Chrysler car.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Nope.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Football cream. Grr!

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Okay, it's football cream. It's football cream. Alright! So, anybody else?

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: I'm taking a computer animation class so I could try to do a logo.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Look at that. Even the receptionist is getting in on the creativity. Very good, very good.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Hello hello!

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #1
quotes.text: Hey, how ya doin'?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Michael Scott.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #2
quotes.text: Hey, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Regional manager.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #2
quotes.text: Hey Michael, nice to meet you

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Excited to talk ideas.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #1
quotes.text: Let's do it, man.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: You know, I want this to be cutting edge. I want it to be fast, quick cuts, you know, youthful, sort of a MTV on crack kind of thing.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #1
quotes.text: That sounds great.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: All right, good, well this is what we have to work with.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: I would like you to meet Andrew Bernard. The 'Nard Dog. Who let the 'Nard Dog out?

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Hoo hoo hoo-hoo!

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: He gives the best back rubs in the office.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: It's true, I give a mean backrub. I also do good aromatherapy [makes farting noise]. Not! You just got 'Nard dogged!

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Now this gentleman right here is the key to our urban vibe.

quotes.speaker: Stanley
quotes.text: Urban? I grew up in a small town. What about me seems urban to you?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Stanley is hilarious. Phyllis is like our Mrs. Butterworth. Kind of a less urban Aunt Jemima.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: These are our accountants. And as you can see they are very different sizes. What you might want to do is kind of a Papa Bear, Mama Bear, Baby Bear thing. That might be kind of fun.

quotes.speaker: Kevin
quotes.text: [looking at Oscar] Mama Bear!

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Who else?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: I think it's great that the company's making a commercial because not very many people have heard of us. I mean, when I tell people that I work at Dunder Mifflin, they think that we sell mufflers, or muffins, or mittens, or... And frankly all of those sound better than paper, so I let it slide.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: You playing that game again?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Second Life is not a game. It is a multi-user virtual environment. It doesn't have points or scores, it doesn't have winners or losers.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Oh it has losers.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I signed up for Second Life about a year ago. Back then my life was so great that I literally wanted a second one. In my Second Life I was also a paper salesman and I was also named Dwight. Absolutely everything was the same. Except I could fly. [shot of Dwight's avatar flying around]

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: [reading off piece of paper] Little girl in a field holding a flower, we zoom back to find that she's in the desert and the field is an oasis. Zoom back further the desert is a sandbox in the world's largest resort hotel. Zoom back further the hotel is actually the playground for the world's largest prison.  But we zoom back further--

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #1
quotes.text: Okay I can tell that your time is valuable--

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Actually I don't get paid by the hour anymore, but thank you, I get paid by the year, so...

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #1
quotes.text: That all sounds really, really ambitious.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Yeah, I know.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #1
quotes.text: Why don't we show you what we did with the Nashua branch?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Mmm. Okay. [commercial plays on laptop, peppy music in background]

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: That's what Nassau came up with? That sucks! [chuckles] Whoa.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #1
quotes.text: That's what we came up with.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Well we can do better than that.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #2
quotes.text: Well the main part of the ad has to stay the same, actually.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #1
quotes.text: Yeah, it's the last five seconds where we have some leeway.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: The waving?

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #1
quotes.text: Well, no, no. You don't have to be waving. That was just what they did. You guys can be clapping. Sitting. Standing outside, inside, whatever. This is where you really get to be creative.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: I need some advice. I've been spending a lot of time making out with Angela lately. But we've been necking, but only necking.  Right? Not actually kissing, our mouths, just the neck on neck. It's just like rubbing slash nuzzling our necks together. It's hot, I'm not going to lie to you , but it's a little weird, but you seem like a guy with answers, so how do I fast track this to get to first base?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: We cannot talk about this... because, someone might hear us.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: We'll use code names.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Angela can stay the same, but we'll change Andy to Dwight.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: That's not different enough.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Dwike?

quotes.speaker: Receptionist
quotes.text: You have a call from Eddie Murphy.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Hello?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: [on speakerphone, Eddie Murphy voice] Shrek! Shrek, I'm a donkey! I'm a donkey, Shrek! [laughing] I'm just kidding. It's me. Hello Ry.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: What?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Okay, calm down. I have a small problem.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: I told you not to call about small problems.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Yeah, well when I call about big problems you don't like that either, so make up you mind, kiddo. Here is the deal, the ad guys that you sent are locking me in a creative box, and sort of ignoring my ideas.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: That's good. They're creative, you're not.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: I'm creative, Ryan.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: It's not part of your job, it's like, maybe you can cook but it doesn't mean you should start a restaurant.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Well actually I can't cook, and I am starting a restaurant. Mike's Cereal Shack. I'm thinking we'll have as many varieties as you can buy in the store.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Okay, I'm not really interested in that right now. I'm delegating creativity to creative professionals. It's a different skills set. Look, I wasn't good at sales, right?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Yeah!

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: But I'm good at managing people who do sales .

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Are you? I don't think you're doing such a good job here, suppressing ideas and creativity.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: All right, let me ask you this, tell me if you think this is creative. When I was five, I imagined that there was such a thing as a unicorn. And this is before I had even heard of one, or seen one. I just drew a picture of a horse that could fly over rainbows, and had a huge spike in its head. And I was five, five years old. Couldn't even talk yet.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Hey guys, um, you know what, we cannot shoot this ad today.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #2
quotes.text: Okay, when should we come back?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: How about never hundred hours, sir.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #2
quotes.text: We were sent here to help out.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #1
quotes.text: Okay I'm not going to argue with this guy. Let's go. Good luck dude.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Hey thanks. Thank you.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: [on phone] Michael, David Wallace.  What is this about dismissing the ad people?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Yeah, I'm glad you called. Ryan is being a little bitch again.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: I'm on Michael.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: What's up my brotha? Listen, David, I would like to do this ad in house. I want to use only the creativity that we have right here in the office. And I will send it to you tomorrow morning, take a look at it, and if you do not think that it's ready to air, send the ad agency back down here, and we'll do it on my dime.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: This is weird.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: I'm willing to stake my entire reputation on it.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Okay, I'll see it tomorrow.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Okay. [hangs up phone] And thus, Michael Scott sealed his own destiny. In a good way.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Has anyone ever come up to you and said, "You're not creative"?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Yes.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Well they're wrong. You are creative. You are damn creative. Each and every one of you. You are so much more creative than all of the other dry, boring morons that you work with.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Who are you talking to, specifically?

quotes.speaker: Kevin
quotes.text: I kind of know what it's like to be in commercials. My nickname in high school used to be Kool-Aid Man. [makes squinty face]

quotes.speaker: Oscar
quotes.text: When I was younger I always wanted to be an actor in commercials. Then I realized I had a brain.

quotes.speaker: Meredith
quotes.text: I'm excited about doing the ad, but I'm not really used to doing videos with so many people around.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: We have three scenes to film, big scenes. We have a song to write. So let's get cracking. Kelly, I want you to do makeup. Oscar, I would like you to do costume design, obviously.  Phyllis, I'd like you look around town and see if we have any celebrities in our local area.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: [gasps] Sue Grafton is at the Steamtown Mall. She's doing a book signing right now.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Okay, okay, Phyllis this is what I want you to do. I want you to go down to the mall. I want you to get in line. I want you to get her to be in this commercial. This would be a huge coupe people. All right? Do not take no for an answer.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Okay.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Does anyone actually know what Sue Grafton looks like? I mean, is she hot or-?

quotes.speaker: Creed
quotes.text: She's crazy hot.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Well then maybe we should just use Angela and say she's Sue Grafton. Would anyone notice?

quotes.speaker: Angela
quotes.text: That's not happening.

quotes.speaker: Angela
quotes.text: I find the mystery genre disgusting. I hate being titillated.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Bye everyone.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Line it up Phyllis.

quotes.speaker: Creed
quotes.text: Get her Phyll.

quotes.speaker: Darryl
quotes.text: [singing] Out of paper, out of stock, there's friendly faces around the block, break loose from the chains that are causing your pain.

quotes.speaker: {andy}, {creed}, {kevin}, {kelly}, {darryl}
quotes.text: Call Michael or Stanley, Jim, Dwight or Creed. Call Andy and Kelly for your business paper needs.

quotes.speaker: Darryl
quotes.text: Dunder Mifflin.

quotes.speaker: {andy}, {creed}, {kevin}, {kelly}
quotes.text: The people person's paper people.

quotes.speaker: Darryl
quotes.text: Dunder Mifflin.

quotes.speaker: {andy}, {creed}, {kevin}, {kelly}
quotes.text: The people person's paper people.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Time out, time out, time out, time out, time out. I thought... I was under the impression that this was going to be a rap.

quotes.speaker: Darryl
quotes.text: What's rap?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Okay, Darryl, wow, you need to learn a lot about your own culture. I'll make you a mix.

quotes.speaker: Darryl
quotes.text: Great.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: News flash. I got some juicy updates on Operation Fallen Angel. Remind me to tell you later.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Hey.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: No talk, I'm animating.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Why don't we take a quick ten second break from that so I can show you what's going on here. [pulls up Dwight's game] Okay, this is Dwight's Second Life. He's on it all the time. So much so that his little guy here has created his own world. It's called Second Second Life, for those people who want to be removed even further from reality.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Are you serious?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Yeah.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Oh my God, he's really in pain.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: [sighs]

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Who's that?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Oh, it's just my avatar guy. Whatever.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: He looks a lot like you. How much time did you spend on that?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Not much, it's just for tracking Dwight so--

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Right... you're a sports writer in Philadelphia? Nice build too.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Yep.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: You have a guitar slung on your back. I did not know you played guitar.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: I... why don't we go back to this animation.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: No no no, I want to see more of Philly Jim. I want Philly Jim.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Ah, show me how this works.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Oh boy.

quotes.speaker: Darryl
quotes.text: [singing in different tune] Out of paper, out of stock, there's friendly faces around the block, break loose from the chains that are causing your pain. Call Michael, Stanley, Jim, Dwight or Creed. Call Andy and Kelly for your business paper needs. Call Dunder Mifflin.

quotes.speaker: {andy}, {creed}, {kevin}, {kelly}
quotes.text: The people person's paper people.

quotes.speaker: Darryl
quotes.text: Dunder Mifflin.

quotes.speaker: {andy}, {creed}, {kevin}, {kelly}
quotes.text: The people person's paper people.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Stop. Stop stop stop stop stop stop. This is not me. This is not my music.

quotes.speaker: Darryl
quotes.text: You're right, it's better than you! It's us! [sings] Dunder Mifflin.

quotes.speaker: {andy}, {creed}, {kevin}, {kelly}
quotes.text: The people person's paper people.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: No, I hate it! I hate it! ...I don't hate it, I just don't like it at all. And it's terrible.

quotes.speaker: Darryl
quotes.text: You're on your own, Mike. [gets up and starts to walk away]

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Okay, you know what. Hold on, hold on Darryl.

quotes.speaker: Darryl
quotes.text: You just said you hated it.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: No. I said I hate the, the style.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: [singing] Break me off a piece of that lumber tar. Snickers bar.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Okay, wow. Wow, this looks uh, terrible.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Break me off a piece of that Grey Poupon.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Andy, Andy, this is a pivotal scene in the ad. And if we don't get this, if we don't nail it, we're going to lose the whole triumph of the moment. The triumph of the will. Now, God, what? What Phyllis?

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: [crying] Well, I got in line to buy Sue Grafton's book and when it came to my turn I asked if she wanted to be in the ad and she said no thank you, but I wasn't supposed to take no for an answer.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: That'a girl.

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: So I kept on asking and they finally threw me out of the store in front of all my friends.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Did you, or did you not get Sue Grafton?

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: [sobbing] No.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Ugh, can somebody give her a tissue please? [Kevin hands her piece of tape]

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: I hope you're not killing yourself on this, because I'm sure it's good enough for Michael's ad that will probably be seen by no one.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Maybe, but it's not good enough for me yet.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Okay. Do you want me to stay?

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: No no, you can go home. I'm good.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Pam is staying late tonight to uh, achieve her dreams. So I'm pretty proud of her, unfortunately she was my ride home.

quotes.speaker: Meredith
quotes.text: You comin'?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: I, ah...

quotes.speaker: Meredith
quotes.text: Piss or get off the pot!

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Dunder Mifflin, this is Pam.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Good morning. [Pam sees breakfast sitting on her desk] Yeah I'm sorry, I looked away for a second and Creed snatched your hash browns.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Thank you.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: You're welcome.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: I worked until about 2:45 AM. And then I had to decide if I wanted to spend the night with Michael editing in his office, and Dwight watching Michael edit in his office, or drive home and probably fall asleep at the wheel and die in a fiery car wreck. I passed out on my keyboard trying to decide.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Let me pour you some bubbly because somebody got to a whole new level last night.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Andy, I can't hear this right now.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: No, no no no, this is good. You know how we haven't really gotten anywhere that I want to get to physically yet? Well, last night, that changed. We're makin' out, I'm kissin' her neck, and cheek and her ear lobe, and she's not really kissing me back. But she closes her eyes and she's like, "Oh D, oh D."

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: She called you D?

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Yeah. D for Andy.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh D.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Oh D.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: [whispers] Oh D.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Oh D!

quotes.speaker: Both
quotes.text: Ohhhhhh D! [laughing] Ohhhh D!

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: I'm about to send the ad to corporate... and it is sent. They'll probably watch it right away. I know I would. Okay. [dials phone]

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: [on phone] Yes?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Pam, please clear my phone lines.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Certainly. [makes beeping noises] Okay, clear.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: They could call at any second now. [sighs] Oh God...I better call.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: [Ten days later] Well, it's been tough. The uh, geniuses at corporate rejected my commercial and tonight they are airing the brain dead version. So welcome one and all to the world premiere of Corporate Crapfest!

quotes.speaker: Everyone
quotes.text: [watching ad] Oh! [clapping and cheering]

quotes.speaker: Bartender
quotes.text: Hey it seemed like a big hit.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: No, it was stupid. People like waving, waving sells. It's not art. Yet we made our ad, the real one was full of humor, and full of depth, and full heart and it was real.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Hey, could you do me a favor? Could you put that in the DVD player?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Hey everybody! Just want to welcome you all to the premiere of the real Dunder Mifflin commercial, the Michael Scott director's cut. Hope you like it.

quotes.speaker: {michaels-ad}'s Ad
quotes.text: [Chariots of Fire theme plays] It all starts with an idea. But you can never tell where an idea will end up. [people passing a Corporate Memo around to each other] Because ideas spread, they change, grow. They connect us with the world. [Kelly catches paper airplane that says "I love you"] And in a fast moving world, where good news moves at the speed of time [newspaper with Andy saying "Hometown Boy Wins Race"], and bad news isn't always what it seems. [Dwight hands Phyllis paper that says "You have a son, and it's me"] Because when push comes to shove we all deserve a second chance. [Stanley finds paper that says "Turn your life around. Now hiring at Dunder Mifflin"] To score. [Jim throws paper in basket, Michael retrieves it; it says "World's Most Creative Boss"] Dunder Mifflin. Limitless paper in a paperless world.

quotes.speaker: Everyone
quotes.text: [claps and cheer]

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Animation? All her by the way. [points at Pam]

quotes.speaker: Bartender
quotes.text: Really?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: I just thought you should--

quotes.speaker: Bartender
quotes.text: The animation was cool.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Thanks.

quotes.speaker: Bartender
quotes.text: Hey listen, you ever been on a motorcycle?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Ahh. [puts his arm around Pam]

quotes.speaker: Kevin
quotes.text: Michael, that was fun.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: That was fun. Next round of drinks is on me, people!

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: [singing] Claude Van Damme, Hair for Men, poison gas, NutraSweet. [speaking] It's gotta rhyme with "piece." Fancy Feast! [sings] Break me off a piece of that Fancy Feast! It's the cat food. Nailed it.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: All right! So, anybody else? No bad ideas. Everybody, let's keep 'em coming... oh, God.  Okay, Toby?

quotes.speaker: Toby
quotes.text: Well, you know how everyone fast forwards through ads these days? Well, what about an ad in slow motion. You know, if they fast forward through it, it'll just seem normal and it will catch your eye. Plus, uh, the slogan could be:

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: This is Pam Beesly, representing our girl next door.  Pretty but nothing special.  You know, but she sort of keeps it real. What you might want to do, is if you could zoom in, like really quick zooms on her. Might be good.  [walking away]  Who else? [pointing] Oh, Creed... is the old guy over there. Don't look at him. You might want to use him to sort of get that Orville Redenbacher dynamic going.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #1
quotes.text: Sure.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #2
quotes.text: Right.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: And if not we can just make him disappear. [walks quickly over to Jim's desk] This is Jim! Halpert. Jim has a very expressive face, don't you Jim? He is like our Mr. Bean.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Okay.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: So do, um, do sad, do the sad face.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: I don't want -

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: No, that's skeptical. Do sad.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Mmm...

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: That's, that's a pirate movie. [Jim stares at Michael] That's annoyed. Well, he doesn't do very well under pressure.

quotes.speaker: Ad Guy #1
quotes.text: [shakes head] Yeah... no.  [Jim turns to Pam with an exaggerated sad face; Pam laughs. Dwight walks towards Michael and the ad men]

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: And anybody else, we can just hire an actor to replace.  Follow me!  Let's get this movin'. [Dwight goes back to his seat, embarrassed]

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: All right, let's start.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: All right!  [sitting down behind Michael's desk] I'm not sure what I'm supposed to be doing, but...

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: You are my producer, you are a suit.  I am the creative genius.  You take care of all the boring stuff, and let my mind just run free.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Yup.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Now, we have eighty-five dollars, and a Sam Goody gift certificate...

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Right.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: ...and we need to be done by 9 A.M. tomorrow.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Mmmhmm.  Why don't you start by telling me what you got.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: We start on a single blank sheet of paper.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Love it.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: And we widen to reveal ancient Rome.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Mm, can't do that.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Okay, we widen to reveal a spaceship blasting out of a woman's womb.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Definitely can't do that.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Bull[censored] man!

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: You know what?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: This is bull[censored]!

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Okay, Scott, why don't you take your head out of the clouds and come back down to planet Earth so we can make a commercial.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Ahhhh!  [sweeps toys off his desk]

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: I'm just doing my job, man.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: If you don't let me pursue my artistic vision, I am going to walk!

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Good!  Fine!  I've got one Andy Bernard that will direct this puppy for half your fee... [dialing phone]

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: No!  No!  Jim, Jim, don't, don't...

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: What?  What?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: No, I can do it.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: What?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: I can do it good.  I can do it good.  Please, don't.  Please.  [kneels in front of desk] Please give me it.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Okay, make a commercial.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: [taps on desk and starts to leave his office] Do you want this open or closed?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Closed. [Michael leaves his office, gives Jim two thumbs up, which Jim returns]

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Hey, everybody, I just got off the phone with David Wallace, and he has given us the go-ahead to make the first ever Dunder Mifflin television commercial.  Huh?

quotes.speaker: Everyone
quotes.text: [applause]

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: I can't hear you! [less applause]  Heard you a little bit less that time.  Must be...

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: We had already applauded.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Okay, okay.  Who could do music?

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: How about Darryl?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Actually, I'm a little concerned about having a black person do the music, because that could create a positive stereotype that could then become a... celestine prophesy, and keep the next Bon Jovi from ever picking up a piano.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Michael is on a mission to prove that he's creative.  Which I think is odd, because Michael actually might be the most creative person I've ever known.  Every day, Michael says and thinks things that no one has ever said or thought before.
